issues.text: Whether the appellant had locus standi to file a petition in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the appellant had locus standi to file a petition in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the order dated March 7, 1962, cancelling the resolution dated May 29, 1961, was made under s.62 or s.72 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the order dated April 18, 1963, can be sustained under s. 72 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether an order under s.62 can be reviewed under s.72 in light of generalia specialibus non derogant.
Whether the Government can review its own order under s.62 citing s.13 of Madras General Clauses Act, or becomes functus officio.
Whether the order dated March 7, 1962, violated s.62(2) by not giving opportunity of explanation to Panchayat Samithi.
Assuming the March 7, 1962 order was under s.72(1), whether there was a mistake of fact or law justifying review under s.72(3).

anchor.surface_text: Now let us assume that the said order was made under sub-s. 1 of s. 72 of the Act. Two objections were raised against the validity

arguments.claim: The order of the Government cancelling the resolution dated May 29, 1961, was made under s. 62 of the Act and, therefore, the said order could not be reviewed under s. 72 thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai, learned counsel for the appellant, raised before us the following points  1  The order of the Government cancelling the resolution dated May 29, 1961, was made under s. 62 of the Act and, therefore, the said order companyld number be reviewed under s. 72 thereof.

arguments.court_reasoning: Order analysis shows it cancelled the resolution under s.62; s.72 cannot review s.62 orders per generalia specialibus non derogant.

arguments.claim: Assuming that the said order dated March 7, 1962, was made under s. 72(1) of the Act, the order dated April 18, 1963, reviewing the said order was invalid inasmuch as the prerequisite for the exercise of the power of review thereunder, namely, the existence of a mistake of fact or law or the ignorance of any material fact, was not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: 2  Assuming that the said order dated March 7, 1962, was made under s. 72 1  of the Act, the order dated April 18, 1963, reviewing the said order was invalid inasmuch as the prerequisite for the exercise of the power of review thereunder, namely, the existence of a mistake of fact or law or the ignorance of any material fact, was number satisfied.

arguments.court_reasoning: There was a mistake of fact, but other flaws like no notice make it invalid.

arguments.claim: The order dated April 18, 1963, was also invalid, because it was made without giving an opportunity to the party prejudiced thereby of making a representation against the making of the said order.

anchor.surface_text: 3  The order dated April 18, 1963, was also invalid, because it was made without giving an opportunity to the party prejudiced thereby of making a representation against the making of the said order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Violates proviso to s.72(1); appellant as representative prejudiced without opportunity.

arguments.claim: The appellant had no personal right in the matter of the location of the Primary Health Center and, therefore, he had no locus standi to file an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Ram Reddi, learned counsel for the State of Andhra Pra- desh, raised a preliminary objection that the appellant had numberpersonal right in the matter of the location of the Primary Health Center and, therefore, he had numberlocus stand to file an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant as trustee/representative has personal right or prejudice; cites Calcutta Gas Co.

arguments.claim: The order of the Government dated March 7, 1962, was not simply a cancellation of a resolution made by the Panchayat Samithi, but a composite order giving directions to the Block Development Officer and, therefore, it fell directly within the scope of s. 72 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: lie argued that the order of the Government dated March 7, 1962, was number simply a cancella- tion of a resolution made by the Panchayat Samithi, but a companyposite order giving directions to the Block Development Officer and, therefore, it fell directly within the scope of s. 72 of the Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Preamble and analysis show it cancels resolution dated May 29, 1961 under s.62.

arguments.claim: As the said order was made under a misapprehension that there was a permanent location of the Health Centre at Dharmajigudem, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under S. 72(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and, as the said order was made under a misapprehension that there was a permanent location of the Health Centre at Dharmajigudem, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under S. 72 3  of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Order was under s.62, not s.72; s.72(3) only reviews s.72(1) orders.

arguments.claim: Even if the order dated March 7, 1962, was passed under s. 62 of the Act, the said order being an administrative one, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under s. 62 itself when the mistake was discovered or brought to its notice.

anchor.surface_text: He would further contend that even if the order dated March 7, 1962, was passed under s. 62 of -the Act, the said order being an administrative one, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under s. 62 itself when the mistake was discovered or brought to its notice.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.62 is quasi-judicial; no review power; functus officio after order; s.13 Madras GCA inapplicable.

arguments.claim: The impugned order was neither made under s. 62 nor under S. 72 of the Act, but it was really passed under the relevant Rules made by the Government in exercise of the power conferred on it under s. 69 of the Act, read with sub-s. (2) of s. 18 thereof, whereunder the ultimate authority under the Act to locate the Health Centre was the Government.

anchor.surface_text: In addition he raised before us a new point which was number argued either before the single Judge or, on appeal, before the Division Bench. of the High Court. He would say that the impugned order was neither made under s. 62 or under S. 72 of the Act, but it was really passed under the relevant Rules made by the Gov- ernment in exercise of the power companyferred on it under s. 69 of the Act,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Dharmajigudem. Later, the Panchayat Samithi at its meeting held on 29-5-61 resolved to shift the Primary Health Centre permanently to Lingapalem villa

arguments.court_reasoning: Rules inconsistent with s.18 vesting power in Panchayat Samithi; rules cannot override statute.

arguments.claim: The learned Solicitor General supported Mr. Ram Reddi on all points and elaborated the construction of the order dated March 7, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor General, appearing for the 4th respon- dent, supported Mr. Ram Reddi on all the points and further elaborated that aspect of the argument which related to the construction of the order made by the Government on March 7, 1962.

arguments.claim: Order dated March 7, 1962 was under s.62, not s.72; analysis of order text shows cancellation of resolution.
s.72 general power does not apply to s.62 special power per generalia specialibus non derogant; cannot review s.62 order under s.72.

holdings.text: The appellant had locus standi to file a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution as a representative/trustee prejudiced by the order.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the appellant had locus standi to file a petition in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution. ... We have, therefore, no hesitation to hold that the appellant had the right to maintain the application under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant as President of village committee collected funds as trustee; personal right includes trustee interest or prejudice; cites Calcutta Gas Co. precedent.

holdings.text: The order dated April 18, 1963 was not made under the Rules under s.69 giving ultimate authority to Government.

anchor.surface_text: Now, we shall first take the new argument advanced by Mr. Ram Reddy ... But a scrutiny of the relevant provisions of the Act shows that the said rules are inconsistent with the provisions of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules make Panchayat Samithi recommendatory only, inconsistent with s.18 vesting power to establish PHC in Samithi; rules cannot override statute.

holdings.text: Rules under s.69 inconsistent with s.18 vesting power to establish Primary Health Centres in Panchayat Samithi; cannot divest Samithi's power.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.18 vests administration including establishing PHC in Samithi; s.69 rule-making cannot transfer power to Government; rules yield to statute.

holdings.text: Order dated March 7, 1962 cancelling resolution dated May 29, 1961 was made under s.62, not s.72.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of order preamble and reasons shows cancellation of specific resolution for lack of 2/3 majority under rules; fits s.62.

holdings.text: s.72 general revision power does not apply to/review s.62 special cancellation power per generalia specialibus non derogant.

anchor.surface_text: The principle generalia specialibus non derogant compels us to exclude from the operation of S. 72 the case provided for under s. 62. ... s.72(3) only reviews s.72(1) orders.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.62 special, s.72 general; general does not derogate special; s.72(3) limited to reviewing own s.72(1) orders.

holdings.text: Government cannot review its own s.62 order; quasi-judicial power, functus officio after order; s.13 Madras GCA inapplicable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.62 quasi-judicial requiring hearing; no review provision unlike s.72; authority ceases power post-exercise.

holdings.text: March 7, 1962 order under s.62 violated sub-s.(2) by not giving Panchayat Samithi opportunity of explanation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.62(2) mandates opportunity before action; no notice given.

holdings.text: Assuming March 7, 1962 order under s.72(1), there was a mistake of fact justifying review under s.72(3).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapprehension that PHC permanently located at Dharmajigudem; facts showed no permanent location as conditions unfulfilled and resolution cancelled.

holdings.text: April 18, 1963 review order invalid for violating proviso to s.72(1) by not giving opportunity to prejudiced party (Dharmajigudem representatives).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso requires opportunity for prejudicial orders; appellant as representative prejudiced, no notice given.

precedents.citation: The Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd. v. The State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in The Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd. v. The State of West Bengal 1 , dealing with the question of locus standi of the appellant in that case to file a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court, observed Article 226 confers a very wide power on the High Court to issue

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd. v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Article 226 confers a very wide power on the High Court to issue directions and writs for enforcement of rights under Part III or any other purpose; persons other than those claiming fundamental rights can approach; ordinarily the right enforced must be personal or individual right of the petitioner
precedents.cited_holding: ordinarily the petitioner who seeks to file an application under Art. 226 of the Constitution should be one who has a personal or individual right in the subject-matter of the petition. A personal right need not be in respect of a proprietary interest it can also relate to an interest of a trustee

anchor.surface_text: The result of the discussion may be stated thus The Primary Health Centre was number permanently located at Dharmajigudem. The representatives of the said village did number companyply with the necessary companyditions for such location. The Panchayat Samithi finally cancelled its earlier resolutions which they were entitled to do and passed a resolution for locating the Primary Health Centre permanently at Lingapalem.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court rightly refused to quash Government order dated April 18, 1963, as quashing would restore illegal order contrary to valid Panchayat Samithi resolution
